The MIC quality measures shall—

Measures of the
				process, experience, efficiency, and outcomes of maternity care, including
				postpartum outcomes.

Measures that
				apply to—

women and newborns who are healthy and at

				birth in low-risk women; and
women and newborns at higher risk.

				apply to—

childbearing

newborns.

pregnancy;

the intrapartum

the postpartum

) may make grants to

text.#text: The

the development of
			 new State and regional maternity care quality collaboratives;

expanded activities of existing maternity
			 care quality collaboratives; and

maternity care initiatives within
			 established State and regional quality collaboratives that are not focused
			 exclusively on maternity care.

The following entities
			 shall be eligible for a grant under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Quality Care for Moms and Babies Act/s:3/ss:a

text.#text:
Quality collaboratives that focus entirely,
			 or in part, on maternity care initiatives, to the extent that such
			 collaboratives use such grant only for such initiatives.

Entities seeking
			 to establish a maternity care quality collaborative.

State Medicaid
			 agencies.

State departments
			 of health.

Health insurance
			 issuers (as such term is defined in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 2791 of the Public Health Service
			 Act

text.#text:
Provider organizations, including
			 associations representing—

health
			 professionals; and
hospitals.

In
			 order for a project or program of an eligible entity to be eligible for funding
			 under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Quality Care for Moms and Babies Act/s:3/ss:a

internal-xref.#tail:
, the project or program must
			 have goals that are designed to improve the quality of maternity care
			 delivered, such as—

text.#text:
improving the
			 appropriate use of cesarean section;

reducing maternal
			 and newborn morbidity rates;

improving
			 breast-feeding rates;
reducing hospital readmission rates;

identifying improvement priorities through
			 shared peer review and third-party reviews of qualitative and quantitative
			 data, and developing and carrying out projects or programs to address such
			 priorities; or

delivering
			 risk-appropriate levels of care.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Quality Care for Moms and Babies Act/s:3/ss:a

text.#text:
Activities
			 that may be supported by the funding under

Facilitating
			 performance data collection and feedback reports to providers with respect to
			 their performance, relative to peers and benchmarks, if any.

Developing,
			 implementing, and evaluating protocols and checklists to foster safe,
			 evidence-based practice.

Developing, implementing, and evaluating
			 programs that translate into practice clinical recommendations supported by
			 high-quality evidence in national guidelines, systematic reviews, or other
			 well-conducted clinical studies.

Developing
			 underlying infrastructure needed to support quality collaborative activities
			 under this subsection.

Providing technical assistance to providers
			 and institutions to build quality improvement capacity and facilitate
			 participation in collaborative activities.

Developing the capability to access the
			 following data sources:

A mother’s
			 prenatal, intrapartum, and postpartum records.

A mother’s medical
			 records.

An infant’s
			 medical records since birth.

Birth and death
			 certificates.

Any other relevant
			 State-level generated data (such as data from the pregnancy risk assessment
			 management system (PRAMS)).

Developing access to blinded liability
			 claims data, analyzing the data, and using the results of such analysis to
			 improve practice.

is for a project or program
			 that focuses on births, at least 25 percent of the births addressed by such
			 project or program must occur in health facilities that perform fewer than
			 1,000 births per year.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
for a project or program located in a
			 State in which less than 25 percent of the health facilities in the State
			 perform less than 1,000 births per year, the percentage of births in such
			 facilities addressed by such project or program shall be commensurate with the
			 Statewide percentage of births performed at such facilities.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Quality Care for Moms and Babies Act/s:3/ss:a

Projects and

develop a plan to
			 identify and resolve data collection problems;

identify and
			 document evidence-based strategies that will be used to improve performance on
			 quality measures and other metrics; and

exclude from
			 quality measure collection and reporting physicians and midwives who attend
			 fewer than 30 births per year.

Any reporting requirements established by a
			 project or program funded under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Quality Care for Moms and Babies Act/s:3/ss:a

text.#text:
minimize costs and

use existing data
			 resources when feasible.

Quality Care for Moms and Babies Act/s:3

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: There are authorized to be appropriated

current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To amend title XI of the Social Security Act to improve
		  the quality, health outcomes, and value of maternity care under the Medicaid
		  and CHIP programs by developing maternity care quality measures and supporting
		  maternity care quality collaboratives.
